briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 21, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and International Warnings
sections.content: Scientists have warned that global warming could surpass the 1.5Â°C threshold more than a decade sooner than anticipated, indicating that the climate crisis is intensifying at an unprecedented rate [81]. This threat endangers the future of the Winter Olympics and Paralympics [70, 72, 78], critically impacts sensitive environments such as snow ecosystems [66], and even threatens the very existence of some nations [59]. Phenomena such as mosquitoes preying on humans due to hunger caused by climate change [50, 73] and rapid shifts in penguin breeding seasons [79] are direct evidence of ecosystem disruption, with widespread pressure mounting, including the insurance industry reaching its limits [61]. This strongly suggests that immediate action is essential to protect humanity's future treatments [57] and global conservation efforts [60].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Domestic Climate Policy and Energy Transition Issues
sections.content: Domestic climate policy and energy transition face several critical issues. As a $1 trillion 'climate adaptation' market emerges, concerns are being raised about South Korea's response capabilities [6], and worries about a 'hasty amendment to the Carbon Neutrality Act' are growing [15, 18]. In particular, there is heated debate over recognizing air-source heat pumps as renewable energy without prior verification [19, 23, 24, 26, 29, 31, 34, 42, 44]. Experts emphasize the urgency of scientific standards and performance verification, warning that such moves could lead to increased electricity consumption and be counterproductive to carbon reduction [23, 26, 35]. Despite increasing demand for renewable energy, RE100 is urging the government to raise its targets [20], and Representative Lee Jae-myung's remarks opening the possibility of new nuclear power plant construction due to the intermittency of renewable energy [40] suggest the need for ongoing discussion on the domestic energy mix.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Corporate and Community Efforts Towards Carbon Neutrality
sections.content: Active efforts from corporations and local communities are underway in various forms to achieve carbon neutrality goals. Global companies such as Schaeffler [2, 22], ABB [4], and Aptiv [55, 71] have achieved the highest 'Leadership A' rating in the CDP Climate Change assessment, recognized for their leading roles in climate change response and water resource management. Domestically, institutional collaborations are active, with Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power and Jeju National University cooperating to achieve carbon neutrality [14], and the Carbon Neutrality Education Center partnering with Lloyd's Register for reduction technology training [10]. Furthermore, Hwaseong City [17, 33, 36, 38] and Ansan Social Solidarity Economy [37] have announced plans for renewable energy facility construction and a 100MW renewable energy initiative, accelerating local-level carbon neutrality implementation. Alongside these efforts, policy attempts to encourage public participation and induce daily carbon reduction are also noteworthy, such as the 2026 revised 'Carbon Neutrality Point System' [9] which increases carbon neutrality points for shared bicycle use, and Chungnam Province's promotion of timber-based public architecture [16].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Social Discourse and Adaptation Strategies in the Era of Climate Change
sections.content: Discussions are actively taking place to formulate social discourse and adaptation strategies in response to the era of climate change. At the World Forum, the impact of climate change on international politics was discussed [1], and the Korea Climate Change Research Institute plans to host a seminar on 'Achieving Carbon Neutrality and the Role of Regions' [5]. In the United States, research on the impacts of climate change on delta regions and watersheds [53, 64] is underway, alongside an emphasis on the importance of tree planting in the age of climate change [52]. Just as plans to preserve San Diego's Sunset Cliffs from climate change are causing resident concerns [54], new social conflicts can arise during the adaptation process. The opinion that 2026 candidates should recognize climate change as an economic issue [69], along with a survey on whether the film and TV industries can drive climate action [68], demonstrates that climate change is already a 'kitchen table issue' [69] across our society and a crucial area for communication.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the severity of the climate crisis, along with various domestic and international response efforts and key issues. Through continuous interest and participation, we must strive to build a more sustainable future. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: Last year, six teams set up their first camp in the US, but due to abnormal weather and high exchange rates, for the second camp before actual games, they gathered in Japan (Okinawa, Miyazaki) and other locations like Taiwan.
